columns.text: In this problem, we'll determine the worth of an investment that pays $25,000 every other year forever, with a discount rate of 7% daily compounding, and occurs one year from today. In addition, we'll determine the value of the payment occurs four years from now instead.

To solve the problem, we will analyze the following details.

| Particulars      |          |
|------------------|----------|
| Annual cash flow | $25,000  |
| Discount rate    | 7% (Compounding daily)       |
| Period           | Forever  |

As the period is infinite, let's discuss what is known as perpetuity.

Perpetuity in finance is an annuity with no fixed maturity date, and this means there are no periods. Since there is no period, perpetuity endlessly compounds.

Proceeding with the computation, let's start by defining the appropriate rate to consider when calculating the value of the perpetuity investment. We'll suppose the timeframe is every two years if the investment pays every "other" year. Because the discount rate accumulates every day, as stated in the problem, we'll compute the two-year effective rate using the effective annual rate computation.
The Effective Annual Rate (EAR) is the annual interest rate on loan after considering the nominal interest rate and period compounding. The EAR refers to the actual rate of the loan.

The effective annual rate (EAR) is calculated using the following formula:

$$ \begin{aligned}
EAR &=\left(1+\dfrac{APR}{m}\right)^m-1
\end{aligned}$$

Where:

$EAR$, which means the effective annual rate\
$APR$, which represent the annual percentage rate\
$m$, which indicated the period

Since the actual investment period is two years and the rate compounds daily, let's determine the number of compounding periods by multiplying two years by the number of days in a year.

$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{Period} &= 2\times365
\\[5pt]
&= 730
\end{aligned}$$

Hence, we'll consider the compounding period of 730 in calculating the effective rate.

Using a 7% annual discount rate and a 730-day compounding period, let's figure out the two-year effective rate. Because the discount rate is a yearly rate, we only divided it over 365 days.

$$ \begin{aligned}
EAR &=\left(1+\dfrac{0.07}{365}\right)^{730}-1
\\[10pt]
&=1.150258359-1
\\[5pt]
&= \boxed{15.03\%}
\end{aligned}$$

As can be seen in our computation, the two-year effective rate of the investment is 15.3%

Next, let's calculate the present value of the investment.

As previously stated, the term has no end because the investment is in perpetuity. We shall apply a specific formula to compute the present value to determine its present value.

The following formula represents the equation to determine the present value of perpetuity:

$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{PV of Perpetuity} &=\dfrac{C}{r}
\end{aligned}$$

Where:

$PV$, which means the present value\
$C$, which represent the constant cash flows\
$r$. which indicates the rate

Next, we'll compute the future value of the investment, assuming it pays to start one year from now. We will consider the present value of the perpetuity investment as the future value, multiplied by the compounding period and rate factor.

We'll use the following equation to determine the future value of the perpetuity investment present value.

$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{FV} &=PV\times\left(1 + r\right)^{t}
\end{aligned}$$

Where:

$FV$, which refers to the future value\
$PV$, which denotes the present value\
$t$, which represent the period\
$r$, which indicate the discount rate
Because the investment pays off one year from now and the rate multiplies every day, we'll consider the compounding period of 365 days.
Next, instead of using the effective rate, we'll use the provided annual rate of 7% divided by 365, as the effective rate is based on a two-years, and the value we're computing is only one year away.
For the next calculation, we'll evaluate the value of the investment if the perpetuity investment begins paying four years from now instead of one year.

To determine the value of the investment, we'll use the present value computation which can be calculated using the following equation:

$$ \begin{aligned}
PV &=\dfrac{FV}{\left(1 + r\right)^{t}}
\end{aligned}$$

Where:

$PV$, which means the present value\
$FV$, which refers to the future value\
$t$, which represent the period\
$r$, which indicate the discount rate

We'll consider the $166,380.09 present value of the perpetuity as the future value. The rate we will use in this case instead of the annual rate is the two-year effective rate of 15.03% and discounting the future value by one period.

As calculated on the earlier steps, the effective rate of the investment is based on two-year since the perpetuity investment pays every other year. Considering the effective rate and compounding it by one period will result in an actual equivalent of four years. 

Therefore, we'll consider the effective rate and discount of only one period in calculating the investment value if payment occurs four years from now.

To summarize, we determined the value of the investment if it starts one year from now is $178,442.82 and $144,645.85 if it starts four years from now by first calculating and considering the present value of the perpetual investment.
